Senators 2, Blackhawks 2

Eric Daze's power-play goal at 5 minutes 47 seconds of the third period lifted Chicago to a 2-2 tie with the Ottawa Senators last night, but the Blackhawks' streak of games without a victory still reached 10 (0-8-2).
Daze converted a deflection from the slot 49 seconds after Ottawa's Shaun Van Allen had given the Senators a 2-1 lead with a short-handed breakaway goal.
Tony Amonte also had a power-play goal for Chicago, which did manage to snap a four-game losing streak.
Amonte's 12th goal tied him for the league lead with Edmonton's Bill Guerin.
Lance Pitlick also scored for the Senators, who have not won in their last six games (0-3-3).
The Blackhawks have not won since a 5-4 victory at home over Nashville on Oct. 24.
Although Ottawa outshot Chicago by 12-4 in the first period, the game remained scoreless after 20 minutes thanks to Blackhawks goaltender Mark Fitzpatrick.
He was tested late in the period, stopping David Oliver on a close chance and several other Senators during an Ottawa power play.
Pithck opened the scoring at 3:07 of the second period when he drove to the net to finish a give-and-go with Alexei Yashin.
Amonte, however, tied it at 6:12 with a power-play goal, the first allowed by Ottawa in four games.
He shoveled a shot past Damian Rohodes after Pal Coffey's drive for the slot deflected off Daze's Stick.

Van Allen gave the Senators a 2-1 lead at 4:58 of the third period. He raced the length of the ice ad beat Fitzpatrick o the stick side after Doug Gilmur lost the puck at the right point during a Chicago power play.
But 49 seconds later - and during the same Blackhawks manpower advantage - Daze tied it at 2-2 by redirecting in Glour's shot for the left point.
Igor Kravchuk apparently scored with 3:35 left in regulation to give Ottawa a 3-2 lead, but the goal was disallowed after video review showed that the Senators' Andras Johansson was in the crease.
The game was officiated by two referees, Dennis LaRue ad Lance Roberts.
